pageData.text: In this investigation, students will culture a motile, a nonmotile, and an unknown bacterial species in <button class='glossary-text'>motility</button> test agar containing TTC. Students will observe the color change in the motility test agar to determine which bacterial species are motile. They will then compare the results of the unknown sample against the results of the two known samples to determine the identity of the unknown.

pageData.text: Flagellated also plays an important part in pathogenesis, allowing bacteria to move (and spread) through body fluids. An example of motile pathogenic bacteria is Heliobacter pylori, the microbe responsible for most ulcers of the gastrointestinal tract. Like other motile pathogens, it uses its motility to swim through mucous in the body toward epithelial host cells, which they then colonize. H. pylori is thought to increase its motility by secreting urease, an enzyme that not only reduces the pH of the acidic GI environment, but also thins out the viscosity of the mucous1. By identifying whether a pathogen is motile, physicians and scientists can narrow down the identity of microbes that infect patients around the world.

1Kaiser, G. (9 April 2022). The Ability to Use motility and Other Means to Contact Host Cells.LibreTexts Biology.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Motility</button> is the ability of a microorganism to propel itself spontaneously. In most bacteria this movement is accomplished using <button class='glossary-text'>flagella;</button> however, some bacteria are able to move by gliding or swarming motility. Flagella are threadlike locomotor appendages that extend outward from the plasma membrane and the cell wall. The presence of flagella is most common in bacilli species of bacteria, (Figure 1) but it can also be found in a few cocci species.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Bacteria with flagella

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Motility</button> allows bacteria to move towards areas with higher nutrient concentrations and away from unfavorable environments, such as areas that are too extreme in pH or temperature.

<button class='glossary-text'>Motility</button> is an important taxonomic tool that allows microbiologists classify species of bacteria. Motility is tested using a semisolid agar medium that allows motile bacteria to “swim” through the agar. A bacteria sample is stabbed into the center of the media and motile bacteria will move away from the line of inoculation. The movement of bacteria through the medium causes the medium to become cloudy. This movement can be observed in an inoculated sample after incubation (Figure 2). Nonmotile bacteria will only grow at the line of inoculation and the rest of the medium will appear clear.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Three test tubes filled with agar showing (from left to right) an uninoculated sample, a positive sample, and a negative sample.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Three test tubes filled with agar showing (from left to right) an uninoculated sample, a positive sample, and a negative sample.

pageData.text: Flagellated <button class='glossary-text'>motility</button> also plays an important part in pathogenesis, allowing bacteria to move (and spread) through body fluids. Not all motile bacteria have flagella. In fact, many bacterial species are nonmotile, so an important step in characterizing and identifying a bacterium is to determine if it is motile or nonmotile.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, test tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.

Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture(s) from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment kit. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older E. coli. culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of the culture to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth labeled “E. coli.”

Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then 
 discard the loop in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Mix the contents of the reactivated or older S. epidermis by tapping or rolling the tube between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of the culture to a fresh tube of tryptic soy broth labeled “S. epidermis.”
Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Empty the alcohol from the disposal jar as described in the Disposal and Cleanup section, but keep the jar for later use.
Incubate the inoculated broth tubes upright in the rack with their caps slightly loose. Both organisms will grow at room temperature; however, they will grow faster around 37° C (99° F).
Extinguish the candle, disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.

Allow between 1 and 3 days of incubation for the broths to become turbid (cloudy). The length of time required for growth depends on the ambient temperature. Do not proceed until both cultures are growing well.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: Under suboptimal conditions, S. epidermis may grow very slowly and incubation times may need to be extended to five days or more.
Prepare to work as described in Steps 1–5. Make sure you also sterilize your inoculating needle.
In Activity 1, you will prepare agar plates by adding melt and pour agar into sterile Petri dishes.  You will inoculate these plates with bacteria in Activity 2.

Clean the work area where you will pour your tryptic soy agar plates. Disinfect the area by applying your 10% bleach solution with a paper towel. Allow to air-dry (this will take approximately 2 minutes), as this increases the effectiveness of the disinfectant.
Caution: Make sure to loosen the caps, or pressure may build up in the bottles when heating, possibly causing an explosion hazard.
Slightly loosen the cap of a nutrient agar bottle (to allow steam to escape when heating).

Caution: To swirl the media, using an oven mitt or pot holder, tighten the cap, and turn the bottle back and forth. If the media has not completely melted, loosen the cap, and microwave it for another 5 seconds. Repeat this process until the media is completely melted, continuously keeping an eye on the media to avoid any explosions.

Place a paper towel in the microwave. Place the bottle on the paper towel and warm it up in 5-second intervals. This step is very important to ensure the media does not explode in the microwave. Use an oven mitt or pot holder to take the bottle with media out every 5 seconds and gently swirl the media in the bottle.
Allow the bottle to cool slightly before pouring the medium onto the plate. The medium should still be liquid, but the bottle should not be too hot to handle.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Photograph of cooled, melted nutrient agar being poured into a Petri dish with the lid lifted.

pageData.text: Note: While working, hold the agar bottle tilted at a 45° angle to exclude dust.
Caution: Do not place the bottles in an ice bath or refrigerator in an attempt to speed the cooling process.

Fill the Petri dish up approximately half way. This should use about a third of the agar in the bottle. Immediately replace the Petri dish lid. Fill two more Petri dishes half way full with the remaining agar in the bottle.
Allow at least 30 minutes for the plate to set. Do not disturb the plate during this time.
Repeat Steps 5–10 with the remaining tryptic soy agar bottles.

Photograph the agar plates after they have set. To photograph, place each plate, facing up, on a piece of white paper with your name and the date of plate preparation handwritten on it. (Include the three agar plates in one photo.)
Dispose of the agar bottles and gloves in the garbage. Wash and dry your hands.
In Activity 2, you will streak an agar plate for isolated colonies. You will use an isolated colony in Activity 3 to test for motility.
Mix the contents of each culture tube by tapping or rolling gently between your palms.

Obtain a loop of broth from the E. coli culture and inoculate about one-quarter of the surface of the agar in your plate in a zigzag pattern as shown in Figure 4. Please note that, for the sake of clarity, the lid of the Petri dish is not shown in Figures 4-7.

pageData.text: Note: Part of correct aseptic technique is avoiding excessive removal of the lid from a Petri dish. Open the lid just enough to insert and move the loop, and use the lid as a shield to keep dust off of the agar surface. Close the lid as soon as you are finished.

Place your inoculating loop in the disposal jar. Take a new sterile loop, rotate the plate about 90°, and pull some inoculum from the first sector of the agar into the adjacent sector, using a zigzag pattern, as shown in Figure 5.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the second sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.

Note: Only take inoculum directly from the mixed culture one time to streak the first sector. Subsequently, you will use a new sterile inoculating loop for each sector, without inserting any of the loops back into the mixed culture.
The second streak should only pass through the first sector once or twice, not repeatedly, to achieve separation of the colonies.
Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar, rotate the plate, and use a new sterile loop to pull inoculum from the second sector into an adjacent one, as shown in Figure 6.

pageData.text: Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar, rotate the plate, and use a new sterile loop to pull inoculum from the third sector into the final one, as shown in Figure 7.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Drawing of a hand holding an inoculating loop which is being used to streak the fourth sector, about a quarter of the surface, of the agar in a Petri dish.

pageData.text: Extra care should be taken in the fourth and final streak to ensure the loop does not touch or pass through the first sector; doing so will prevent the isolation of single colonies.

Invert the plate so it is lid-side down, and using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the outside of the bottom of the plate with the names of the organism and the date of inoculation. Your plate is now ready for incubation.
Repeat Steps 1-7 for the other cultures.
Allow your cultures to incubate.
Unless otherwise instructed, keep your E. coli and S. epidermis cultures for later use. The unknown culture may be disinfected and discarded as described in the Disposal and Cleanup section.

Your streak plates may be incubated at approximately 25° C (77° F). After approximately 48 hours of incubation, examine your plate with the lid on. Do not remove the lid of the Petri dish during any observations, as doing so may result in contamination. Do not be alarmed if little or no growth is evident at 48 hours.

Prepare to photograph your plates. Avoid the use of the flash, which will simply be reflected off of the lid. Do not remove the lid of the Petri dish to take photos. You may need to experiment with lighting conditions and camera angles to get the best pictures in your work space.
Observe and photograph the plate again at approximately 72 and 96 hours. Once you have visible colonies, your cultures will be ready to perform Activity 3, the Motility test.

In this activity, you will inoculate <button class='glossary-text'>motility</button> test medium that has had TTC added to it. The TTC creates a red color in the medium when motile bacteria move through it. You will inoculate three motility test medium tubes – one with known motile bacteria, one with known non-motile bacteria, and one with unknown bacteria whose motility you will be asked to determine.

typeBefore.text: Note: Make sure to follow aseptic technique. Also, make sure that the inculcating is straight and has been sterilized before proceeding. You may need to straighten the needle between inoculations. If you do so, make sure to sterilize the needle before and after straightening it.

pageData.text: Dip the point of the inoculating needle in the jar of alcohol solution and then flame the needle. To ensure the needle is sterilized, you will need to make sure the entire length is flammed. Be sure the inoculating needle has a minute to cool before touching it to your bacterial culture, as extreme heat will kill bacteria.
Using proper aseptic technique, gently touch a bacterial colony to pick up bacteria.

With your free hand, uncap a new tube of <button class='glossary-text'>motility</button> test medium agar and flame the mouth of the tube. Stab the needle with the bacteria sample once straight down to about two-thirds the depth of the medium. Then, remove the needle by pulling straight up, along the same path the needle made. Make sure that the needle does not touch the sides or the neck of the tube.
Note: If the needle touched the sides of the tube, sterilize it with the surface disinfectant before using it again.

Note: If you touch the side of the tube with the handle of the inculcating needle, the handle should be flamed lightly, but not so much that it gets hot. Hold the handle of the wire loop close to the top, away from the needle, at an angle that is almost vertical. Lightly flame the handle, making sure not to get the handle too hot or near your figures. Hold the inculcating needle away from the flame and allow it to cool before you continue with the rest of the steps.

Flame the mouth of the tube and cap the <button class='glossary-text'>motility</button> test medium tube to finger tightness and then backwards a quarter turn, and then place it back into the test tube rack. Place the used needle point-down in the jar of alcohol. Use the grease pencil to label the tube with the bacteria sample used, the current date, and your initials.
Repeat Steps 1–4 using your broth culture of S. epidermis.

Repeat Steps 1–4 using your broth culture of the unknown microbe. When labeling the <button class='glossary-text'>motility</button> test medium tube after inoculation, use the identification number of the unknown microbe.
Take all inoculated and labeled tubes and incubate them for 18–24 hours in the warmest part of your house. Do not incubate the tubes in sunlight.

A workflow diagram of the investigation. To prepare, disinfect the work surface, prepare the disposal jar, and prepare the cultures. In Activity 1, melt agar and prepare agar plates in the petri dishes. Then, allow the plates to cool. In Activity 2, streak each plate with the appropriate bacteria using the isolation streak plate technique. Then incubate the plates. In Activity 3, inoculate motility test medium agar with the designated bacteria. Then label the inoculated agar tube with the bacteria name. Repeat this until 3 tubes are inoculated. Next, incubate the tubes for 18-24 hours. After incubating, record the bacteria motility.
